fields.description:
We use Crowd as an openid provider. It would be a huge improvement to have OpenID 2.0 support. Specifically we need "identifier_select" support.

http://openid.net/specs/openid-authentication-2_0.html
fields.summary: OpenID 2.0 and identifier select support

fields.description:
None of the client libraries include any license information. Including a licenses tag could help integration efforts.

http://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Licenses
fields.summary: please include license in pom files

fields.description: When try to create a page it shows a system error, so the only workaround is just to delete the page draft in order to repair this problem.
fields.summary: Fail When Try to Create a Page

fields.description:
Integrated applications detect that a Crowd session has been invalidated when they send a validation request to Crowd. If {{session.validationinterval}} is set then sessions will only be validated after a certain delay has passed. This creates a window where an application will allow use of a session that has been logged out elsewhere.

Setting the interval to zero means logged out sessions will be detected immediately, at the cost of a large number of extra requests to Crowd, which will hurt performance.

If Crowd published a log-out event to all applications then the window would be closed without requiring applications to check each time.
fields.summary: Crowd to publish session log-out event to all integrated applications

fields.description:
As of now Crowd does not have the ability to retrieve multiple CNs from LDAP server. When an LDAP user have multiple CN, Crowd will just retrieve the primary CN and ignore the other CNs.

It would be great if Crowd could convert all of those CNs into [aliases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+a+User%27s+Aliases] for each application that the user assigned to.

This way, user could use all of the CNs associate with the user when they access all application that integrated with Crowd
fields.summary: Crowd to Support Multiple CNs

fields.description:
When searching for groups via the REST API wiht the following URL

{code}search?entity-type=group&restriction=active%3dtrue{code}

only the groups of the 1st directory defined for the connected client are returned.

If there are more than one directory linked to the connected client, groups from the 2nd/3rd/4th/... are not returned by the REST call.

Can you confirm this is a bug ?

Thx
fields.summary: REST group search does not return all the groups in Crowd

fields.description:
We have a lot of groups in Crowd which are organized in nested groups like
- group 1
 -- group 1.1
 -- group 1.2
    -- group 1.2.1
 
So it would be great to have some kind of treeview in the "Group Browser" view instead of displaying all groups flat.


Is that something that would be realistic?

Thanks a lot!
fields.summary: Treeview for nested groups

fields.description: In order to run integration tests of the new LDAP dynamic groups feature, we need the ability to start and stop a LDAP server that supports dynamic groups.
fields.summary: Set up a test framework with a LDAP server that supports dynamic groups
Upgrade Hibernate to 3.5

fields.description: Would be great to have a feature to permit users when they access Confluence application to have a link to sign up for themselves.
fields.summary: Allow Users sign-up for Crowd Accounts on their own

fields.description:
Currently Crowd offers very basic functionality of synchronizing Users/Groups/Memberships based on a specified Base DN, which will sync all users/groups/memberships that are located in subtrees below the Base DN. It would be helpful to AD admins if Crowd can also sync objects from trusted forests so that Crowd would be able to sync group/user members from the external forest.

To do this though, Crowd must be able to resolve the ForeignSecurityPrincipal (in the local domain specified by the BaseDN), which is a reference object to a securityPrincipal in the external domain. See: http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc755427%28v=ws.10%29.aspx
fields.summary: Provide ability to sync objects (users/groups/memberships) from another forest through Active Directory's external/forest trust

fields.description:
When setting up an LDAP Delegated Authentication directory in Crowd, the "User Password Attribute" is shown as required. The description reads: "The attribute field to use when manipulating a user password."

A Delegated directory should not need this field at all since Crowd won't be changing the password. We should hide this field during the directory setup.
fields.summary: LDAP Delegated Authentication directories should not require a User Password Attribute

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Log into crowd;
# Select 'Users' --> Click on username --> select 'Attributes' tab
# Enter an invalid LDAP attribute name, such as '_invalid'
# Click 'Add >>" button

The same issue exists in the REST API.

The rules for well-formed LDAP attribute names are described by the 'keystring' production of the grammar, see http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4512#section-1.4
fields.summary: Crowd permits adding user attributes that are not valid LDAP attribute names

fields.description: Provide a mechanism within Crowd to allow escalated privileges to manage users within specific directories without providing privileges to perform more general Crowd administration tasks such as creating or configuring directories and applications.
fields.summary: Allow User Management Rights Per User Directory

fields.description:
When generating an SSO token, Crowd should hash both the Remote Address and the User Agent but it seems that Crowd 2.5.1 isn't using the User-Agent for authentication when generating an SSO token using the REST API.

If one requests an SSO token using 'Firefox' as the User Agent and then tries to validate the returned SSO token with 'IE' as the User Agent, Crowd does not return any error. Examples of the two HTTP requests can be seen below:

*First request : Ask Crowd to create an SSO token:*

{code} 
POST /crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/session HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<authentication-context>
  <username>homer</username>
  <password>password</password>
  <validation-factors>
    <validation-factor>
      <name>User-Agent</name>
      <value>Firefox</value>
    </validation-factor>
  </validation-factors>
</authentication-context>
{code}

*Crowd returns:*

{code}
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
X-Embedded-Crowd-Version: Crowd/2.5.1
X-Crowd-User-Management-Version: 1.2
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=EE9AA13C6188234A64CB1216E53D8AFD; Path=/crowd
Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, no-transform
Location: http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/session/kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00
Content-Type: application/xml
Content-Length: 366
Date: Fri, 09 Nov 2012 16:05:24 GMT
Connection: close

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><session expand="user"><token>kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00</token><user name="homer"><link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/user?username=homer"/></user><link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/session/kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00"/></session>
{code}

*Second Request : Ask Crowd to validate this token but pass a different User-Agent:*

{code}
POST /crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/session/kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00 HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<validation-factors>
  <validation-factor>
    <name>User-Agent</name>
    <value>ie</value>
  </validation-factor>
</validation-factors>
{code}

*Crowd accepts the token, (despite the incorrect User Agent), which suggests that this is a serious security issue as it is no longer hashing the User Agent:*

{code}
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
X-Embedded-Crowd-Version: Crowd/2.5.1
X-Crowd-User-Management-Version: 1.2
Set-Cookie: JSESSIONID=ECF61E962CD3F857ED2E0DFAC6041961; Path=/crowd
Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, no-transform
Content-Type: application/xml
Content-Length: 366
Date: Fri, 09 Nov 2012 16:06:02 GMT
Connection: close

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?><session expand="user"><token>kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00</token><user name="homer"><link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/user?username=homer"/></user><link rel="self" href="http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/session/kyHw09WHXxSFHSrStseQgQ00"/></session>
{code}
fields.summary: 'User-Agent' not taken into account by Crowd when validating SSO token with the REST API
Crowd documentation is ambiguous and should be updated regarding Crowd not sending email when a new user is created

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Run Crowd in a platform where the default character encoding is not UTF-8.
# Set the password reset email template to a text containing non-ASCII characters.
# Send a password reset email for some user.

Expected result: an email containing correctly-encoded UTF-8 characters.

Actual result: non-ASCII characters appear as question mark characters (?).
fields.summary: Non-ASCII characters in email messages are transformed to ???? when the platform encoding is not UTF-8

fields.description:
The Crowd session for Apache pages is kept alive indefinitely until the browser is closed (removing the authentication cookie seems to have no effect, subsequent visits to the same page despite having all cookies removed from the browser will still allow the user to view the page without requiring authentication).

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Authenticate (via Basic Auth) to a Apache site (which requires Crowd Authentication), make sure that the authentication is successful, and you are able to view the site
# Remove all cookies and caches from the browser (Clear browsing data), and try to navigate to the same page 
Notice that you do not get the same Basic Auth prompt again, in fact, you are able to view the page immediately, without having to re-authenticate.
fields.summary: Expire Crowd-Apache Sessions after a timeout, or when the cookie is removed

fields.description:
At the moment, when synchronisation happens, it only stores & displays the last total execution time. 

It would be nice to have a detailed break down per stage.
It would be even nicer to have historic break down information for each synchronisation.
fields.summary: Show detailed breakdown of synchronisation information.

fields.description:
h5. Symptoms

If Crowd has been running with JDK 1.6 in the past, and then is changed to JDK 1.7, some plugins will fail to load, due to cached dependencies.

The following message appears in the log file:

{code:none}2012-10-31 09:13:09,641 main ERROR [atlassian.plugin.manager.PluginEnabler] Unable to enable plugin crowd-rest-plugin
com.atlassian.plugin.osgi.container.OsgiContainerException: Cannot start plugin: crowd-rest-plugin
	at com.atlassian.plugin.osgi.factory.OsgiPlugin.enableInternal(OsgiPlugin.java:430)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.impl.AbstractPlugin.enable(AbstractPlugin.java:237)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.impl.AbstractDelegatingPlugin.enable(AbstractDelegatingPlugin.java:213)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.manager.PluginEnabler.actualEnable(PluginEnabler.java:114)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.manager.PluginEnabler.enable(PluginEnabler.java:99)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager.addPlugins(DefaultPluginManager.java:713)
	at com.atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager.init(DefaultPluginManager.java:166)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.plugin.CrowdPluginManager.init(CrowdPluginManager.java:69)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.plugin.CrowdPluginManager.onApplicationStartedEvent(CrowdPluginManager.java:82)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:601)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.invoke(SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.java:36)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher$2.run(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher$1.execute(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:28)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.dispatch(AsynchronousAbleEventDispatcher.java:56)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.EventPublisherImpl.invokeListeners(EventPublisherImpl.java:151)
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.EventPublisherImpl.publish(EventPublisherImpl.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.console.listener.StartupListener.contextInitialized(StartupListener.java:106)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.listenerStart(StandardContext.java:4205)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.start(StandardContext.java:4704)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.addChildInternal(ContainerBase.java:799)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.addChild(ContainerBase.java:779)

	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.deployDescriptor(HostConfig.java:675)

	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.deployApps(HostConfig.java:502)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.start(HostConfig.java:1315)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.HostConfig.lifecycleEvent(HostConfig.java:324)
	at org.apache.catalina.util.LifecycleSupport.fireLifecycleEvent(LifecycleSupport.java:142)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.start(ContainerBase.java:1061)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHost.start(StandardHost.java:840)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase.start(ContainerBase.java:1053)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardEngine.start(StandardEngine.java:463)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardService.start(StandardService.java:525)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardServer.start(StandardServer.java:754)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Catalina.start(Catalina.java:595)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:601)
	at org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap.start(Bootstrap.java:289)

Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Unresolved constraint in bundle com.atlassian.crowd.rest-plugin [18]: Unable to resolve 18.0: missing requirement [18.0] package; (&(package=com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common)(version>=2.5.1.1)) [caused by: Unable to resolve 13.0: missing requirement [13.0] package; (&(package=javax.activation)(version>=0.0.0.1_006_JavaSE)(version<=0.0.0.1_006_JavaSE))]
	at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix.resolveBundle(Felix.java:3409)

h5. Workaround

Please see the KB here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Crowd+2.5+unable+to+be+used+after+upgrading+to+JDK+1.7

Crowd support Wildcards

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
According to [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Confluence+3.4+or+earlier], integration between Confluence 3.4 and below with the latest Crowd is possible, and you need to copy {{CROWD/client/crowd-integration-client-X.X.X.jar}} from Crowd and copy it to
{{CONFLUENCE/confluence/WEB-INF/lib}}. In fact, the latest Crowd might not have the atlassian user class, and thus make Confluence 3.4 and below returned 404 error. If this jar file is replaced by Crowd 2.2.7 and below, it will work fine due to class inside.

*Steps to replicate*
# Install latest Crowd e.g Crowd 2.5.1
# Copy over {{CROWD/client/crowd-integration-client-X.X.X.jar}} to {{CONFLUENCE/confluence/WEB-INF/lib}}
# Startup Confluence

*Workaround*
Copy {{crowd-integration-client-2.2.7.jar}} instead of the latest Crowd as it is the last Crowd that contains atlassian user class
fields.summary: Unable to use latest crowd integration jar file in Confluence 3.4 and below

fields.description: Make the interface introduced in CWD-1860 generic, so code that makes search queries can rely on the returned type of collection.
fields.summary: Use generics for ContextMapperWithRequiredAttributes

fields.description:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2835 implemented a configuration for password complexity message for Internal Directory(hand to hand with passwordRegex). 

As [~mbeaucha] points ot in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2835?focusedCommentId=409130&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-409130 we need to investigate how to add this functionality with LDAP / AD. 

Quick googling points out we could get the message from AD (ntSecurityDescriptor). Not sure about OpenLDAP.
fields.summary: Password Complexity Message for Remote Directories ( Open LDAP /  AD etc )

fields.description:
Steps to Reproduce.
1. Go to applications tab and add a new application.
2. In the next step try resolving a local address with ipv6 enabled. Try proceeding and you should get a invalid remote address error.

Expected behaviour:
Resolved IP address should not included the scoped interface identifier.
fields.summary: IPV6 address resolved with scoped interface identifier needs to be stripped.

fields.description:
When the combination of User DN prefix and Base DN fails to parse as a valid LDAP name, the following message is displayed on screen (see attachment): "No results were found from your search. org.springframework.ldap.NameNotFoundException: [LDAP: error code 32 - No Such Object]; nested exception is javax.naming.NameNotFoundException: [LDAP: error code 32 - No Such Object]; remaining name '/'".

A better error message should inform about the invalid name, e.g., "User Search DN could not be parsed: Invalid name: obviouslywrong,dc=example,dc=org".

Steps to reproduce:
# Create or update a LDAP connector.
# In field "User DN", enter some text that does not parse as a valid component of a DN (see picture).
# Push "Test search".
fields.summary: Improve error message when 'Test search' fails

fields.description:
The form to create or update a connector or a delegated directory has two fields labelled "User DN". One of them is in the second tab, and has the following description: "Connect to the directory server using the supplied username". The second one is in the third tab and has this description: "This value is used in addition to the base DN when searching and loading users. An example is ou=Users. If no value is supplied, the subtree search will start from the base DN".

Note that the syntax for the value of these fields is different. In the first case, it must by a fully qualified DN, while in the second case, it is just a component that is prepended to the base DN.

It would be nice to have different labels for these two fields to reduce confusion.
fields.summary: Two form fields with identical label when creating/updating a connector or delegated directory

fields.description: When an user changes their password we need to invalidate all their tokens in Crowd as they should no longer be valid.
fields.summary: Crowd to expose a REST API to clear a user's tokens

fields.description:
There's a scenario where default Crowd group memberships will not sync over to Confluence/JIRA during initial login. If Confluence/JIRA has synced with Crowd _prior_ to the user logging in to Confluence/JIRA, the user will be placed into the correct groups in Crowd but not in Confluence/JIRA.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Inside Crowd: create an internal Crowd directory. In the 'Options' tab, set it to add users to some default groups upon initial authentication
# Inside Crowd: create a user in the internal directory but do not place him in groups
# Inside Confluence or JIRA: create a Crowd Server directory, and trigger a synchronization from Crowd
# Inside Confluence or JIRA: log in using the Crowd user

h4. Expected result
* User is added to default groups in Crowd
* User is added to the same default groups in Confluence

h4. Actual result
* User is added to default groups in Crowd (/)
* User is NOT added to any groups in Confluence (x)

This is alleviated during the next FULL sync from Confluence/JIRA, whether automatic or triggered manually. However, incremental syncs will NOT sync the membership info over, thus creating a discrepancy between Crowd and Confluence/JIRA.

h4. Workaround
* Restart Confluence/JIRA. This will trigger a full sync from Crowd on application startup
* Or, if the Crowd Server user directory is set to use full sync (the incremental sync option is unchecked), you can trigger a sync manually to get the memberships over
fields.summary: Default Crowd group memberships not added to JIRA/Confluence if directory sync has occurred

fields.description: To reproduce, see the steps in CWD-1763, but instead of creating a new LDAP connector, create a new Remote Crowd.
fields.summary: Remote Crowd password lost when Test Connection button is used before saving

fields.description: Crowd should return error on creating users with trailing/leading characters on usernames and emails.
fields.summary: Email addresses with trailing/leading white space should return error

fields.description:
I have multiple Atlassian tools in my environment.  I recently picked up Crowd to be the one ring to rule them all.  Unfortunately, it seems Crowd has no concept of user icons, yet every Atlassian app seems to have their own.

Can you please also centralize user icons since Crowd is the one source for user information to Atlassian apps?
fields.summary: Be the source of user icons for Atlassian apps

fields.description:
cert.fr@cassidian.com reported the following vulnerability:
== Type ==
Information Disclosure

== Product ==
Atlassian Crowd

== Severity ==
Medium

== Description ==
The crowd.token_key cookie, used as a token to authenticate on all Atlassian applications, is marked as HttpOnly.
However, the Crowd 500 error page (/crowd/console/500.jsp) displays this cookie?s value, breaking the HttpOnly behavior.
fields.summary: Crowd leaks the value of the HTTP only 'crowd.token_key' cookie on the crowd/console/500.jsp page

fields.description:
We have configured our 3 domain controllers as single directories in our crowd instance. If one of our dc goes down, no more logins are possible.
Every connected service is going timeout on login.

Attached you can find a log file written during the described behaviour.

We use redundant dc infrastructure to avoid such a vault. Please describe how we can handle this in crowd.

Cheers,

Daniel
fields.summary: No Logins are possible if one configured Active Directory is down

fields.description:
Crowd shows an {{UnknownHostException}} when the hostname given for a connection can't be resolved, but also when a node referral points to a host that can't be resolved. It would be better to make a clear distinction, so users know that turning off "Use Node Referrals" may help them to use that directory.

Detection would need to be a heuristic.
fields.summary: Show a clearer error when an UnknownHostException is due to a node referral

fields.description:
Crowd appears to do a DNS lookup of the configured Base DN and it fails to synchronize with the LDAP server.
# The same LDAP can be browsed using Apache Directory Studio
# Integrated Crowd in JIRA works fine with the same LDAP server.
(i) The LDAP connection settings use an IP address for connecting (for example: ldap://10.1.1.1:389).

The reason being, Crowd is attempting a DNS lookup of base DN (for example is the base DN was {{dc=abc,dc=def,dc=com}}, crowd attempts to do DNS lookup of adc.def.com which does not exist and fails).
fields.summary: Synchronization Failure - DNS Lookup Attempted for Base DN
Improve LDAP logging for LDAP errors

fields.description: It should be possible to upload csv files for user imports directly from the browser. Our Crowd users are managed by non-technical users, they should not have to deal with logging in to the server itself.
fields.summary: Allow csv files to be uploaded directly from browser

fields.description:
When a user logs in to a delegated authentication directory we fetch their memberships. This process currently fetches details of the groups that user is a member of, rather than just testing for membership.

Improve performance by only testing for membership, taking into account nested groups and the different ways membership can be defined.
fields.summary: Directory synchronisation retrieves all group memberships when synchronising an individual membership

fields.description:
When Crowd is fetching group memberships it also fetches the users. For synchronisation, we already have the user definitions and only care about the names of the members.

Improve synchronisation performance by only fetching those names.
fields.summary: Don't re-fetch users while fetching memberships during synchronisation

fields.description: The com.atlassian.crowd:crowd-integration-client-rest depends on commons-httpclient which has security issues (see http://osvdb.org/59003 for more details). HttpComponents fixes it in version 4.0. It would be nice to get rid of this transitive dependency.
fields.summary: Replace commons-httpclient with Apache HttpComponents

fields.description: It seems a shame that the search restrictions available using REST do not include a *not* restriction. This oversight limits the value of the searching interface.
fields.summary: Create a SearchRestriction representing negation (not)

fields.description:
To reproduce:

# Create a new Connector, advance to the second tab ("Connector")
# Make some changes in the fields. Use an invalid combination of inputs so the connection will not work (e.g., bad admin username)
# Before saving, click on the Test Connection button.
# The form is reloaded, an error message is displayed. The changes made in Step 2 to the following fields are lost, while the other field values are preserved:
** Use node referrals (resets to unchecked)
** Use paged results (resets to unchecked)

Seems related to CWD-1763
fields.summary: User input in some fields of the Directory Connector form is lost when the connection test fails

fields.description: This is to improve mitigation of XSS vulnerabilities.
fields.summary: Set Crowd JSESSIONID as HTTPOnly in the default configuration

fields.description: When a connection is being updated and the password has been left blank, 'Update' leaves the old password unaffected. However, 'Test Connection' ignores the old password and uses a blank instead. 'Test Connection' should use the same details that would be used after an Update.
fields.summary: 'Test Connection' uses a blank password instead of the existing password

fields.description:
As a Delegated Directory user we feel that the option of locking an account after a given number of failed authentication attempts is missing, as is possible with Internal Directories. In case of an account being locked, the account owner would have to ask a Crowd admin to unlock their account. 

An even better solution to this problem would be to include the possibility to enforce the user to reset the account password via the external ldap server before Crowd would allow the account unlocking; or even via an encrypted link sent to the user's email address.
fields.summary: Provide option to lock user accounts for Delegated Directories after Maximum Invalid Password Attempts reached

fields.description:
Currently Google can use the Crowd token for authentication but Crowd can't use the Google token, hence users need to login to Crowd first so that Google can use the Crowd token to make the SSO work.

It would be nice to have users authenticate with Google and have Crowd use the Google token for authentication with the applications connected with Crowd. In other words, have it the other way around.
fields.summary: Allow using a Google account session to log in to Crowd for SSO

fields.description:
Hi Joseph,

This is the other item I was discussing this morning in our catch-up.
Happy to work through if this is implemented as a separate end-point or a modification of the existing one depending on how the code is structured etc.

Crowd currently returns the username in the "name" attribute of a User REST response. If an alias has been setup for the user and application it will return the alias in the "name" attribute instead. If no alias has been set up it will return the username. In order to support account linkage detection we need the User REST response to contain a flag that tells us if an alias has been set up or not.
fields.summary: Crowd to return alias (empty or not) in user REST response

fields.description:
Related to CWD-210.

This is to allow Lasso to implement remember me functionality by issuing a long-lived cookie when the user has selected "remember me" option. 

Preferable we would like to use the same rest end-point via POST (/session) but happy to use a separate one if necessary.
fields.summary: Dynamically specify the expiry period for session cookies on login

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 18th March 2019|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

I wanted to let you know that we have released cross-domain Single Sign-On in [Crowd Data Center 3.4|https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-4-release-notes-966041084.html] 

You can download Crowd Data Center from here: https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/download/data-center

Please note that in order to use cross-domain Single Sign-On in Crowd you will need Crowd Data Center license.

You can create your evaluation license for Crowd Data Center here https://my.atlassian.com/license/evaluation

If you need any assistance with the Crowd Data Center installation you can follow our Getting started guide https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/installing-crowd-data-center-935369773.html

We hope that you will enjoy it as much as we do!

Please reply directly to my email to share your feedback or just add your comments in this ticket. We'd love to hear your thoughts!

Best regards,

Marek Radochonski
Senior Product Manager, Crowd
mradochonski@atlassian.com
 
{panel}
fields.summary: Can't edit synchronization interval due to Crowd as SSO

fields.description:
The FastDev plugin bundled when an application is run through AMPS currently breaks in Crowd. This means that we wait a minute for the plugin to fail before Crowd is usable.

Expose the eventPublisher to plugins and make sure we cope with web Conditions without a default constructor.
fields.summary: Provide resources used by fastdev plugin

fields.description: CONNECTOR directory has support empty Base DN to be configured which is definitely helpful for our customers. I think it would be a lot better if we also provide this to DELEGATION type of integration as some customer that have a huge user base does not want to use CONNECTOR and they can't take advantage of this new feature.
fields.summary: Support empty Base DN definitions in a DELEGATION directory
Resolve issues running Crowd in a cluster

fields.description:
At the moment, When a user tries to reset a password with a invalid token, the token expiry message is shown after user has entered the password rather than redirecting much earlier. 

Ways to reproduce:
1. Generate a user password reset request and follow the link after 24 hours or just change the token and reach the url, the user will be able to type in password and then will be redirected to generate a new request.
fields.summary: Password Reset Token Expiry should be handled before resetting password

fields.description:
When a new user is created by posting to http://localhost:8095/crowd/rest/usermanagement/latest/user the new user is created without any of the attributes specified in the XML. For example:

{noformat}
<user name="foo" expand="attributes">
      <first-name>foo</first-name>
      <last-name>foo</last-name>
      <display-name>foo foo</display-name>
      <email>foo@example.com</email>
      <active>true</active>
      <attributes>
      <attribute name="foo"><values><value>foo</value></values></attribute>
    </attributes>
      <password>
        <link rel="edit" href="/user/password?username=foo"></link><!--  -->
        <value>pyramid</value>
      </password>
    </user>
{noformat}

It would be nice to be able to create a new user with attributes with a single REST call, without having to call /user/attributes separately.
fields.summary: Creating new users using Crowd REST ignores <attributes> element

fields.description:
Under Linux operating systems the Oracle JDK can no longer be installed through the packaging system, and requires admins to download and run a separate installed. Installing OpenJDK is far easier and we should support that.

Crowd runs against OpenJDK during development, and there are no known issues, but we should extend that to a full acceptance test run against OpenJDK.
fields.summary: Officially support OpenJDK

fields.description: Currently JIRA and Confluence standalone bundles the JDK when installed, and it would be consistent if Crowd was to do the same.
fields.summary: Bundle the JDK with Crowd standalone installation

fields.description: The Crowd setup checklist is showing old versions rather than Crowd's current requirements. Fix them.
fields.summary: Fix versions in Crowd Checklist

fields.description:
Currently, the Hibernate3BatchProcessor is very hard to extend, mostly because there is no way to access the internal currentSessionHolder. 

For Stash, we need to integrate with Spring transaction management and not manage the transactions directly on the Hibernate sessions. More specifically, we do not want to be opening and closing sessions through the Hibernate api directly.
fields.summary: Make Hibernate3BatchProcessor extendable

fields.description: Because some of the Crowd DAOs currently rely on other DAOs by implementation class, we cannot apply Spring AOP on them.
fields.summary: Crowd DAOs in persistence-hibernate3 should inject by interface, not implementation class

fields.description: Delete a group, then recreate it, with the same name that used to be used to restrict pages. Once the user do that, and make himself a member of the group, once Crowd does its synchronization he is accessing pages that he shouldn't gain access based on the restrictions.
fields.summary: Possibility to Access Restricted Pages With Recreated Group

fields.description: LDAP exceptions from some servers include invalid characters (ASCII nuls) that cannot be serialised into XML. We should filter those characters before attempting to pass the error back in a SOAP message.
fields.summary: LDAP exceptions with invalid characters cause exceptions during SOAP seraliasation

fields.description:
h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Delegated LDAP directory in Crowd
# Login using any LDAP user(s) into Crowd, so that these users and their groups are copied to Crowd's database
# Create another duplicate Delegated LDAP Directory with the same exact settings as the LDAP directory created earlier
# Navigate to {{Crowd >> Users >> Import Users >> Directory Importer}}
# Set the Source Directory as the Delegated LDAP Directory created earlier (with the users), and Destination Directory as the duplicate Delegated LDAP Directory with no users in it. Try to import.

This will always fail with this exception: 
{code}
2012-08-29 21:16:26,793 http-8240-5 ERROR [console.action.dataimport.DirectoryConfirmation] java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: argument credential cannot be null
com.atlassian.crowd.importer.exceptions.ImporterException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: argument credential cannot be null
{code}

h3.Why this is important
Some of our customers need to duplicate their delegated directory users to another directory which can be used for testing. Asking the users to login manually for each of the user, just to get their data copied to the DB is definitely a daunting task, which can be avoided, if the import is successful
fields.summary: Not possible to import LDAP users into another LDAP directory using Directory Imported (argument credential cannot be null)

fields.description:
When a user or group name filter is too general, it will return LDAP entities that don't have the required fields. These should be warned about (since we're visiting more LDAP entities than we probably should, and that will make the sync slower), and then filtered out, as if they were part of the existing filter.

They should not result in a fatal log message that prevents the sync from completing.
fields.summary: Ignore and warn about failure to find name attribute

fields.description:
If you have Write permissions on your LDAP and try to modify a group (either the description or the active field), it may fail with this error:
{code}
2012-08-24 10:22:55,139 http-8095-5 ERROR [console.action.group.UpdateGroup] org.springframework.ldap.AttributeInUseException: [LDAP: error code 20 - ATTRIBUTE_OR_VALUE_EXISTS
: failed for     Modify Request
        Object : 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
            Modification[0]
                Operation :  add
                Modification
    description: test
: ERR_254 Trying to add existing value {0} to attribute description]; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.AttributeInUseException: [LDAP: error code 20 - ATTRIBUTE_OR_V
ALUE_EXISTS: failed for     Modify Request
        Object : 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
            Modification[0]
                Operation :  add
                Modification
    description: test
: ERR_254 Trying to add existing value {0} to attribute description]; remaining name 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: org.springframework.ldap.AttributeInUseException: [LDAP: error code 20 - ATTRIBUTE_OR_VALUE_EXISTS: failed for     Modi
fy Request
        Object : 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
            Modification[0]
                Operation :  add
                Modification
    description: test
: ERR_254 Trying to add existing value {0} to attribute description]; nested exception is javax.naming.directory.AttributeInUseException: [LDAP: error code 20 - ATTRIBUTE_OR_V
ALUE_EXISTS: failed for     Modify Request
        Object : 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
            Modification[0]
                Operation :  add
                Modification
    description: test
: ERR_254 Trying to add existing value {0} to attribute description]; remaining name 'cn=Durarara,ou=groups,ou=system'
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.SpringLDAPConnector.updateGroup(SpringLDAPConnector.java:1299)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteDirectory.updateGroup(DbCachingRemoteDirectory.java:370)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.updateGroup(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:553)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:597)
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:307)
{code}

Crowd is attempting to Add the description to LDAP, regardless of whether it exists or not.  In this case, the description was empty, and the Active checkbox was unchecked.  When the page refreshes, the Active box is checked again (because of [CWD-2033|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2033]), and a user will try to uncheck it and Update again, which causes Crowd to attempt to Add another empty description.  Since a blank description value exists, it throws the duplicate attribute error as attribute:value pairs must be unique.

Crowd should either perform a modify if a description exists, or be able to swallow the error as it is essentially harmless since the description value is already present.

h3. Workaround for LDAP Admins to Manage Group Memberships
It has been reported that this error may affect an admin's ability to edit group memberships.  If you *are comfortable manipulating your LDAP directly*, use the following method to work around this limitation:
# Download and install [Apache Directory Studio|http://directory.apache.org/studio/].
# Create a new connection to your LDAP using the same bind credentials that Crowd authenticates with.
# Add/Remove user memberships from within the LDAP tree.
fields.summary: LDAP group edits fails due to duplicate attribute exception on description field
Upgrade JWebUnit to version 3

fields.description:
Customer would like to be be able to  have a centralized location that stores user access logging for all of the applications using Crowd as a user directory.

Valve logging hacked to work in Crowd is not a viable solution to this issue.
fields.summary: Add centralized user access logging for Crowd

fields.description:
Writing practical listeners for RemoteDirectorySynchronisedEvent is difficult, since that event only says which directory was synchronised. It doesn't say if any users, groups or memberships changed, or how many, or who/what. This leads to a lot of extra work on the listeners part to determine which entities were affected, and to update them accordingly.

This event should be changed to add metadata about the synchronisation just completed: 
 * a way to tell it was for a new directory sync,
 * lists of users added, removed or changed,
 * lists of groups added, removed or changed,
 * lists of (user-group and group-group) memberships added or removed, and
 * counts of users, groups or (user-group and group-group) memberships added, removed or changed

To avoid memory issues, the event should stop tracking the individual affected entities after some threshold, and switch to only tracking the counts. Listeners can then use this information to determine (for example) if any users were affected, and if not skip reindexing them.
fields.summary: Publish users, groups, memberships affected in synchronise events

fields.description:
It seems that by using JDK 1.6.0_29, Crowd login doesn't work as expected. The following error occurs in logs:
{code}
2012-08-04 00:12:21,971 http-8495-22 ERROR [crowd.integration.springsecurity.CrowdSSOAuthenticationProcessingFilter] Unable to set Crowd SSO token
org.codehaus.xfire.XFireRuntimeException: Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: Unexpected end of ZLIB input stream
org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: Unexpected end of ZLIB input stream
	at org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault.createFault(XFireFault.java:89)
	at org.codehaus.xfire.client.Invocation.invoke(Invocation.java:83)
	at org.codehaus.xfire.client.Invocation.invoke(Invocation.java:114)
{code}
AND
{code}
2012-08-04 00:15:55,680 http-8495-9 ERROR [crowd.console.action.Login] Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: chunked stream ended unexpectedly; nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.XFireRuntimeException: Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: chunked stream ended unexpectedly
org.springframework.security.AuthenticationServiceException: Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: chunked stream ended unexpectedly; nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.XFireRuntimeException: Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Couldn't parse stream.. Nested exception is com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxIOException: chunked stream ended unexpectedly
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.springsecurity.CrowdAuthenticationProvider.translateException(CrowdAuthenticationProvider.java:290)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.springsecurity.CrowdAuthenticationProvider.authenticateUsernamePassword(CrowdAuthenticationProvider.java:153)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.integration.springsecurity.CrowdAuthenticationProvider.authenticate(CrowdAuthenticationProvider.java:91)
{code}

Changing to JDK 1.6.0_26 seems to resolve the issue.
fields.summary: Can't login in Crowd when using JDK 1.6.0_29

fields.description: Crowd allows session tokens to be stored in-memory (fast) or in a database (persistent). A key-value store such as Redis may be a better choice.
fields.summary: Use a shared key-value store for session tokens

fields.description:
When our server hardware reboots we need to manually restart Crowd.

As a server we think it should startup automatically during OS boot.
fields.summary: Crowd does not auto-start as a service

fields.description: ApacheDS has fixed bugs upstream. Upgrade the version used for testing Crowd to the latest 1.5 release to ensure we can test against the widest range of behaviour.
fields.summary: Upgrade ApacheDS used for testing

fields.description:
Some of the Crowd code currently uses {{CompositeName}} when constructing DNs. This class parses according to JNDI rules, so forward slashes need to be escaped correctly (CWD-2875, etc.) to avoid splitting before passing to LDAP.

Instead, we should use {{javax.naming.ldap.LdapName}} consistently. This involves changing one interface ({{com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.name.Converter}}) in the internal API.
fields.summary: Use LdapName consistently when manipulating DNs

fields.description:
I would like to be able to designate owners of a Group, and allow the group owner to add/remove users from the group.

The standard ldap groupOfNames objectClass includes an 'owner' attribute; the posixGroup objectClass does not :(
fields.summary: Delegated group admin

fields.description: {{MembershipsController}} uses com.megginson.sax:xml-writer to generate XML. Now we can rely on a StAX implementation in the JDK, use that instead to avoid bundling another library.
fields.summary: Use StAX instead of XMLWriter to generate memberships

fields.description:
It would be useful for users to be able to store an SSH public key in Crowd through the UI.

This would allow users to provision for systems like [http://code.google.com/p/openssh-lpk/wiki/Main] that use keys lodged in LDAP. Making the key available to integrated applications would simplify use of authenticated SSH.
fields.summary: Allow storage of SSH public keys from LDAP in Crowd

fields.description:
./build.sh 
Buildfile: build.xml

init:

assistant:
Changing Tomcat's connector port to ${crowd.tomcat.connector.port}

BUILD FAILED
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/xpath/XPathAPI

Total time: 0 seconds
fields.summary: build.sh fails with JDK 7u5: NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/xpath/XPathAPI

fields.description:
Synchronisations in Confluence fail when sAMAccountName and User Logon Name casing does not match (in Active Directory), or where the case has been changed after an initial synchronisation to Confluence.

We have a ticket where the casing does not match, or may have been changed from the initial casing in one field and not the other, which causes every second synch to fail, and removes the affected user's group memberships. Every subsequent synch is successful and restores group memberships.

This occurs up to version 4.2.11 of Confluence (the current version).

h4. Resolution
* For users - fix the casing in AD so that the User Logon Name (pre-Windows 2000) matches the User Logon Name, and matches what is in Confluence, and synchronise again.
* For groups - fix the casing in AD so that the Group Name matches what is in Confluence, and synchronise again.
fields.summary: When sAMAccountName casing does not match cn (User Logon Name (pre-Windows 2000) does not match User Logon Name), or casing of a user or group name has changed from original casing, synchs fail and access is affected

fields.description:
h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom object class in LDAP, (tested this with Apache DS) set the object's parents to the default organizationalPerson (for Apache DS, exactly the same as inetOrgPerson's parent):
!customobject.jpg!
# Create a user entity that uses this custom object class instead of the default inetOrgPerson
# Modify the LDAP connector in Crowd, and set the User Object Class to this new custom object class, and set the user object filter to {{(objectClass=connieuser2)}} . Set the Modify User Attributes and the Modify User permissions.
# Sync the directory, notice that the user is synced correctly.
# Try to modify the user's Firstname, Lastname, or the Email Address. Notice that the UI shows *Update Successful*, but the changes are reverted (unable to modify those attributes). (see: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-2888) . Note however, that password changes are reflected correctly in the LDAP server. Only the firstname, lastname and email address change is ignored.
fields.summary: Full Support for Custom LDAP Object Classes

fields.description:
To support a multi-crowd single database setup we require the Crowd environment configuration to be externalised from the Crowd database. 

Ideally this would be file based so that we can control the config easily by Puppet.
fields.summary: Externalised Crowd Config

fields.description: For operational monitoring it would be good to have some mechanism to poll Crowd to receive information on application health.
fields.summary: Health Check and Recovery Procedure

fields.description:
Hello there.

A customer found a possible bug when using IPV6 address.

h5. Problem

When using IPV6 (0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1) in the remote address of all my application defined in Crowd it fails with the following {{ERROR}}:

{noformat}
2012-08-02 00:02:09,550 http-8095-5 WARN [crowd.manager.proxy.TrustedProxyManagerImpl] Received invalid IP address: 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1%0
{noformat}

But the 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 is the IPV6 equivalent of 127.0.0.1. After disabling IPV6 from the Network Interfaces all started to work properly.

The *%0* was added automatically:

{panel}According to RFC 4007, a zone identifier is attached to the textual
representation of an IPv6 address by concatenating "%" followed by
<zone_id>, where <zone_id> is a string identifying the zone of the
address. However, RFC 4007 gives no precise definition of the
character set allowed in <zone_id>. There are no rules or de facto
standards for this. For example, the first Ethernet interface in a
host might be called %0, %1, %en1, %eth0, or whatever the implementer
happened to choose.
{panel}

Thanks in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: ::1 cannot be a trusted proxy with some IPv6 configurations

fields.description:
This is easily reproducible in Apache Directory Server 1.5 (occurs in all other directory types as well, but we will use the Apache DS example here)

The user objects in Apache DS are normally created with the following object classes:
# inetOrgPerson
# organizationalPerson
# person
# top

When you create a Apache DS connector in Crowd, Crowd automatically sets the user object class to inetOrgPerson. If you change the user object class from inetOrgPerson to say, organizationalPerson, this issue will then be observed when you edit user attributes such as first name, last name, email, etc. (does not occur with password changes). 

Editing a LDAP user's firstname or lastname will result in a *Update Successful* response in the UI, but in actual fact, the firstname and last names are not updated in either Crowd, nor the LDAP repository. We should have seen LDAP Error 65 thrown here, due to the attribute <-> object Class mismatch but we do not.
fields.summary: No errors thrown in the UI when user attribute update fails with objectClass <-> Attribute mismatch (Custom objectClass)

fields.description: Remove the mysql drivers from our distribution.
fields.summary: Unbundle the MySQL drivers

fields.description: The fix for CWD-2760 relies on the fix in Apache DS for [DIRSERVER-766|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DIRSERVER-766] in 1.5.1 (released November 2009). This can result in membership definitions being treated (incorrectly) as case- or whitespace- sensitive. The fix is to upgrade to a current Apache DS. A workaround would be to ensure all groups and memberships are consistent in case and spacing.
fields.summary: Crowd relies on bug fix in Apache DS 1.5.1

fields.description: Plugins that perform bulk operations on directories (e.g. group changes) need to (or at least should) lock the directories. It's much nicer to get this component injected than having to go find it.
fields.summary: Export an DirectoryLockManager (from embedded crowd) for use by plugins

fields.description:
Currently, if users follow the [Configuring Crowd to talk to Confluence|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Confluence] and [Configuring Crowd to talk to JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Confluence] documents, they may end up creating multiple directories when only one is needed.

The current documentation, while technically correct, suggests the idea that each application needs its own directory. 

Perhaps we can refer at that point to some overview page that describes how Applications, Directories etc all work together, and that you create a directory in Crowd for each external directory you want to map -- NOT for each application you want to map to your applications.
fields.summary: Help Crowd admins understand how to model their directories and applications

fields.description: Some role information is still sitting in the directory permission ldap directory permission screens
fields.summary: Some lingering Role references

fields.description:
CrowdHttpTokenHelperImpl.java:67 searches for the Crowd SSO token in cookies presented with the request. It does this by iterating over the cookies and exiting on the first cookie of the right name. This means that if two cookies with the same name - but different domains - are present, the one that Crowd tests is arbitrary. 

Crowd should either:
1. search cookies in order from longest domain to shortest (so more specific tokens override less specific ones)
OR
2. return a set of SSO tokens to test rather than just one (so that override behaviour is controlled higher up).

This is a pretty esoteric bug, requiring different crowd servers servicing different overlapping domain namespaces (in my case, a test Crowd instance handling requests from tank.sydney.atlassian.com, and the global Crowd instance handling .atlassian.com)
fields.summary: CrowdHttpTokenHelperImpl.java doesn't search cookies correctly

fields.description: Do we want to stop the creation of groups with trailing spaces from all directory types?
fields.summary: Refuse to create users and groups with trailing whitespace

fields.description: Crowd warns about disabled plugins on startup (CWD-2583) by checking for plugins that are disabled and required. This misses the case where a plugin is entirely missing. Fix the check to also fail when those plugins are absent.
fields.summary: Check for missing plugins on startup
Spring warning caused by XFire customEditors.xml
Supply a REST user session resource with a DELETE operation

fields.description:
Synchronisation with Active Directory fails with groups that contain a slash due to {{MicrosoftActiveDirectory.postprocessGroups}}. The result of {{group.getDn()}} is passed into Spring LDAP and is treated as a JNDI {{CompositeName}}, split on the slash.

We need to turn it into an {{LdapName}} to ensure it is passed through correctly.
fields.summary: Fetching group memberships containing slashes fails with Active Directory

fields.description:
h3. Symptoms

When you try to update the "Configuration" tab of a delegated authentication directory, it fails with the error message "There was an error in updating the directory. Please check the fields to ensure all entries are valid.".

To attempt to get around this, I tried entering the password in the "Connector" tab, but this did not help. The "Configuration" tab seems to be the only one affected.

h3. Steps to Duplicate

# Create a "Delegated Authentication" directory and save.
# Go to the "Configuration" tab, and with or without changing a value, then click "Update >>"

h3. Workaround

# Take note of the settings of the directory
# Delete the directory
# Re-add the directory using the settings you wanted to change to
fields.summary: Can't update "Configuration" tab in a "Delegated Authentication" directory

fields.description: Acegi Security became Spring Security. The last stable release as Acegi was back in 2008. With support for recent Spring Security we should remove support for obsolete versions.
fields.summary: Remove Acegi Security support

fields.description:
We have additional attributes in our LDAP directory beyond those that can be retrieved with Crowd. We would like to configure Crowd to retrieve these attributes.

An example of this is being able to report on user's business unit. This data is essential to our ability to report back the business units how many users they have on our platform to demonstrate the value the Atlassian suite is providing. In the future this might be required for intra-organizational billing.

The longer term value for this would be to be able to push this data down to the applications and have it show in a user's profile.
fields.summary: Support retrieval of user metadata from directory

fields.description: /rest/syncfeedback should return a 404 and empty JSON dictionary when no synchronisation feedback is available, rather than the error report from an NPE.
fields.summary: Return a 404 when syncfeedback is not available

fields.description:
The incremental sync with AD does not play well with duplicate groups. For example:

# Set up an AD with multiple groups with the same CN.
# Do a full sync. Note the group is ignored because the sync detects multiple groups (as was implemented in CWD-2504).
# Add a user to one of the groups and do and sync again. 
# (BUG) The group you changed will now appear in Crowd. 

The problem is that the incremental sync will only see the group that changed and incorrectly assume that there is now only one group.

# Restart crowd and sync again. This will be a full sync.
# The group will have again disappeared from Crowd because the full sync again detects the duplicate groups.

So basically when Crowd does a full sync it will make a duplicate group disappear. However, the duplicate group may appear if one of the two groups is changed before an incremental sync.
fields.summary: AD Incremental Sync may result AD duplicate groups appearing and disappearing after synchronizations

fields.description:
From discussion with Yilin:

Our support engineers generally recommend against giving write access from Crowd/JIRA/etc to LDAP because of network security. We recommend admins manage their users directly from LDAP. 

An example setup: if you want to have JIRA public sign-up and read-only integration with LDAP for internal users/employees, configure JIRA to write to an internal user directory for public sign-up. (Crowd's internal user directory, or one in JIRA? would need write access to Crowd)

Other relevant details:

* Passwords are always in LDAP - both delegated and connector. Passwords only in Crowd when using an internal directory.
* Group membership is in LDAP with connector, Crowd with delegated. When using delegated, no group information is inherited from LDAP at all.
* Application permissions (space access, project permissions) always in application
* Most attributes in LDAP aren't brought into Crowd/JIRA. Internal directories can have attributes added to them to track stuff like phone numbers.
* You CAN disable or even delete JIRA's internal directory, but it can cause serious problems if there are users in it.
fields.summary: Help customers understand trade-offs of configurations - diagrams/models
